title-group.article-title: Fermentation of Asparagus cochinchinensis extracts with endophytic Aspergillus aculeatus TD103 enhanced their photo-protective effects against UVB radiation

abstract.p: Ultraviolet B (UVB) radiation severely damages human skin by causing DNA damage, oxidative stress, and collagen degradation. This study explored the photoprotective properties of Asparagus cochinchinensis extracts fermented with endophytic fungus Aspergillus aculeatus TD103. Compared to the unfermented control, TD103-fermented A. cochinchinensis demonstrated stronger radical scavenging and ferric ion reduction abilities in vivo, significantly reduced intracellular reactive oxygen species (ROS) and increased the antioxidant enzymes including heme oxygenase-1 (HO-1), superoxide dismutase (SOD), and catalase (CAT) in UVB-induced HaCaT cells. It also downregulated the expression of the AP-1 and MMP genes, reduced the content of matrix metalloproteinase (MMP-1) and increased type I procollagen amino-terminal propeptide (PINP) levels in UVB-induced HaCaT cells. Non-targeted metabolomics and HPLC quantification revealed that elevated sarsasapogenin content may critically contribute to enhanced photoprotective capacity in Asparagus cochinchinensis. The safety assessment of fungus TD103 revealed that this strain was not drug resistant and did not produce mycotoxins, thereby indicating its safety for application. Eye irritation tests demonstrated the safety profile of the fermented extract, indicating negligible irritant potential. The TD103-mediated fermentation markedly potentiated the photoprotective capacity of A. cochinchinensis, ​providing a viable biotechnological platform for sustainable cosmeceutical development targeting UV-induced skin damage.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Ultraviolet (UV) radiation is a critical and ubiquitous factor that affects the health of the skin. Its impact on oxidative processes within the skin has been the subject of extensive scientific investigation over the past few years [1]. Research indicates that UVB radiation can increase the level of intracellular reactive oxygen species (ROS) and damage the extracellular matrix (ECM), collagen, and elastin, which form the core support and function regulation system, ultimately resulting in skin aging [2]. Therefore, it is imperative for the development of skin care products to mitigate the oxidative processes caused by UVB radiation [3].

Antioxidant enzymes in skin cells effectively eliminate ROS, maintaining cellular redox homeostasis [4]. Among them, heme oxygenase 1 (HO-1) is an enzyme involved in heme breakdown which can quickly respond to various oxidative stress conditions, thereby protecting cells from oxidative damage. The main function of superoxide dismutase (SOD) is to scour superoxide anion free radicals (O₂⁻), thereby preventing the oxidative damage of cell structure by free radicals. Catalase (CAT) catalyses H₂O₂ to prevent the toxic damage caused by the accumulation of H₂O₂. These enzymes constitute a powerful antioxidant system. Procollagen type I, supports the texture between skin cells and serves as a precursor to collagen, which is essential for skin [5]. Matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs), which disrupt collagen fibres present in the extracellular matrix (ECM) of the dermal skin layer. Upon UVB-induced damage, an imbalance between these two proteins occurs, leading to wrinkles and skin laxity.

Several cosmetic formulations incorporating natural ingredients have been developed to mitigate the oxidative process, as well as to promote skin health [6]. Traditional Chinese medicine (TCM)-based fermented cosmetics are an extension of natural cosmetics. They are produced by slowly fermenting TCM plant materials with microorganisms to release active substances from the plants. These substances are then modified, transformed or decomposed by microbial enzymes to obtain valuable bioactive substances that are more easily absorbed by the skin and enhance the efficacy of skin care [7]. Fermentative strains have been reported to have a significant effect on the biological metabolism and pharmacological activities of the substrates. However, the strains commonly used in this field still face several challenges, including low compatibility between the strain and the substrates, as well as the limited biological efficacy [8].

Microorganisms that inhabit a plant for at least part of its life cycle without causing any noticeable disease are referred to as endophytes [9]. The long-lasting coevolution between endophytic organisms and their host plants has led to the evolution of special biotransformation abilities in these microorganisms [10]. Endophytes are capable of efficiently transforming plant metabolites, thereby affecting the active substance content and efficacy of medicinal plants. Kong et al. (2019) utilized Aspergillus cristatus CB10002, a probiotic endophytic fungus isolated from Chinese Fu-brick tea, to recycle Huazhenghuisheng oral-liquid (HOL) residues to produce valuable anthraquinones. After a 35-d fermentation period, this method yielded approximately 2.0 mg/g of Citreorosein and 7.5 mg/g of total anthraquinones, underscoring its economic competitiveness. The endophytic fungus CA3-A, identified as Talaromyces coprophilus from the roots of Astragalus mongholicus, was screened for its biotransformation activity [11]. Its effects on host metabolism were evaluated through co-culture with the host roots, revealing significant alterations in primary metabolites and the conversion of secondary metabolites, particularly in terpenoids, phenols, and flavonoids [11]. Therefore, plant endophytic fungi can serve as essential microbial resources for fermentation in TCM plants.

Asparagus cochinchinensis, a perennial plant belonging to the Liliaceae family, is indigenous to East Asia and widely distributed across regions such as China, Japan, and Korea [12]. A. cochinchinensis is extensively employed for the treatment of a variety of conditions, including constipation, fever, pneumonia, stomach-ache, acne, and urticaria [13]. The traditional Chinese medicine A.cochinchinensis is abundant in diverse active ingredients, including polysaccharides, amino acids, flavonoids, and saponins [14]. Among these ingredients, saponins have been demonstrated to possess antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, anti-aging properties, along with neuroprotective effects [15]. Sarsasapogenin, a crucial component of saponins, has been widely investigated for its anti-inflammatory, anticancer, and cell-protective activities [16, 17].

Recently, the antioxidant, anti-tumour and anti-inflammatory activities of A. cochinchinensis have also been identified [18, 19]. However, there is limited research on the cosmetic effects of A. cochinchinensis, particularly its potential in mitigating photodamage.

The present study employs endophytic fungus to ferment the aqueous extract of A. cochinchinensis with the goal of investigating whether the resulting fermentation product exerts protective effects on skin, specifically against photodamage caused by UVB radiation. An investigation of the cell factors underlying the effects of A. cochinchinensis fermentation products will establish a scientific basis for their utilization in Chinese medicine as cosmetic ingredients for photooxidative damage. To assess the efficacy of microbial fermentation in the utilization of A. cochinchinensis ingredients, untargeted metabolomics was used to analyse the variation in metabolites before and after fermentation. We also studied the contents of sarsasapogenin with (High Performance Liquid Chromatography) HPLC analysis, which is a bioactive constituent of A. cochinchinensis that exerts protective effects.

sec.title: Isolation and identification of endophytic fungi
sec.p: Healthy A. cochinchinensis samples were obtained from the southern mountain region of Dao County, Hunan Province, China (111°17′-111°56′E, 25°09′-25°50′N). The isolation of endophytic fungi from the collected plants was conducted in accordance with a previously established protocol [20]. First, the plant tissues were rinsed with clean water to remove any residual dust particles. They were then subjected to a soaking process involving the use of 70% ethyl alcohol for a period of 2 min, followed by a 3-minute immersion in a 5% sodium hypochlorite solution. This was then followed by another 2 min of soaking in 70% ethyl alcohol. A total of three rinses with sterile water were performed between each step. The tissue sections were then transferred to plates containing potato dextrose agar (PDA), which were then incubated at 28 °C for seven days. The fungal mycelium was promptly transferred to new PDA plates for purification upon emergence from the tissue slice. The purified fungi were then stored at 4 °C for future use.

The process of identifying endophytic fungi was accomplished through a combined approach of morphological and molecular analysis. The morphological features of isolate TD103 were observed via lactophenol cotton blue staining. Molecular analysis was based on sequence analysis of the ribosomal DNA internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region. The fungal DNA was extracted from approximately 100 mg of fungal mycelia via a Rapid Fungi Genomic DNA Isolation Kit (Sangon Biotech, Shanghai, China). The specific DNA of each fungus was amplified via polymerase chain reaction (PCR) in a total volume of 25 µL, containing 12.5 µL of Premix Taq™, 0.5 µL of primer ITSl, 0.5 µL of primer ITS4, 1 µL of template DNA (20 ng/µL) and 10.5 µL of ddH2O. Amplifications were completed via a PCR instrument (ETC 811, Thermal Cycler, Eastwin Scientific Equipment, Inc., China). The following conditions were used for PCR: initial denaturation at 94 °C for 3 min, followed by thirty cycles of 94 °C for 60 s, 56 °C for 60 s, and 72 °C for 60 s, with a final extension at 72 °C for 10 min. The amplified PCR products were subjected to electrophoresis on a 1% agarose gel, after which they were sent to Sangon Biotech Co., Ltd., Shanghai, China, for Sanger sequencing. The BLAST search program was used to compare the isolate sequences with those in the National Centre for Biotechnology Information (NCBI) database to identify the closest matched species(https://blast.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Blast.cgi) [21]. The neighbour‒joining method, as utilized in MEGA 11 software, was employed to generate a phylogenetic tree, with 1,000 replicates conducted for bootstrap analysis [22]. The identified strains were subsequently deposited and preserved in the Guangdong Microbial Culture Collection Center (GDMCC) for long-term storage and further research.

sec.title: Preparation of A. cochinchinensis aqueous extract and fermentation products
sec.p: According to method of Lee [23], 100 g of A. cochinchinensis was boiled in 1 L of distilled water at 100 °C for 1 h and subsequently filtered. The process was repeated twice, and the filtrate was further mixed to obtain the A. cochinchinensis aqueous extract.

To prepare the culture medium for fermentation, the A. cochinchinensis aqueous extract was further dissolved by adding 12 g of potato dextrose water medium powder per Liter. After the powder was dissolved, the mixture was subjected to sterilization at 121 °C for 20 min and then allowed to cool naturally. Subsequently, 10 mL of the endophytic fungal spore suspension (1 × 10^8 CFU/mL, listed in Table 1), was inoculated into 200 mL of the medium for fermentation. The fermentation conditions were set at 28 °C for 72 h, with a shaker speed of 120 revolutions per minute. After fermentation, the mixture was filtered to remove the fungi. Both the aqueous extract and the fermentation products of A. cochinchinensis were subjected to lyophilization via a vacuum freeze dryer (LGJ-10, Song Yuan Freeze Dryer, China) for further analysis and testing.

caption.p: Endophytic fungi isolated from A. cochinchinensis

sec.title: Cell culture and viability experiments
sec.p: Human immortalized epidermal cells (HaCaT) were purchased from Cellverse Bioscience Technology Co., Ltd., Shanghai, China. The cells were cultured in Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium (Gibco, SCA, USA) supplemented with 1% penicillin‒streptomycin sulphate (Gibco, CA, USA) and 10% foetal bovine serum (TOCYTO, CO, USA) at 37 °C in a humidified environment with 5% CO2. Only cells that were passaged fewer than 30 times were utilized for the experiments.

Cell viability was measured using CCK-8 (Cell Counting Kit 8, Thermo Fisher Scientific Instruments Ltd. China). To assess the cytotoxicity of the fermented A. cochinchinensis, cells were exposed to various fermented A. cochinchinensis for a period of 24 h. After incubation, the old culture medium was discarded, and the medium was replaced with fresh DMEM supplemented with 10% CCK-8. The cells were then incubated at 37 °C for 1 h. After incubation, the optical density was determined at a wavelength of 450 nm via a microplate spectrophotometer. The concentration of the fermentation product that maintained a cell viability rate of ≥ 90% was defined as the non-toxic concentration. All application concentrations of the test samples referred to in the subsequent text were confirmed to be within this non-toxic range.
A UVB cell damage model was established in which HaCaT cells were exposed to UVB irradiation at a dose of 10 mJ/cm2 with a UVB light therapy lamp (G8T5E, Nidec Sankyo Corporation, Japan).

To screen the fermentation products of endophytic fungi with photoprotective effect, cells were treated with various fermented A. cochinchinensis before UVB irradiation for a period of 24 h. HaCaT cells were then exposed to UVB at a dose of 10 mJ/cm2. Fresh medium supplemented with lyophilized powders of the fermentation products (0.6 mg/mL) were added to the plates and incubated for 12 h. The viability of the cells was assessed with absorbance measurements taken at 450 nm.

The protective effect of TD103 fermentation products at concentrations from 0.2 to 1 mg/mL on HaCaT cells under UVB damage was examined. Cells without any treatment served as the blank control (Normal), while cells cultured without the addition of fermentation broth and subsequently exposed to UVB irradiation were designated as the model control (Model). Cells treated with Asparagus extract addition and UVB exposure were used as the unfermented control (The uninoculated control). Cell viability was assessed following the instructions provided in the CCK-8 assay kit.

sec.title: In vitro antioxidant activity assay
sec.p: The ability of the unfermented and fermented A. cochinchinensis to scavenge DPPH free radicals was determined via the method described by Liu’s research [24], with a few minor adaptations. In brief, 100 µL of the test sample (1–10 mg/mL) was mixed with an equal volume of DPPH solution (0.2 mmol/L, Sigma‒Aldrich, WI, USA). Subsequently, the mixture was allowed to incubate at ambient temperature for 30 min in the dark. Following incubation, the absorbance was quantified with a microplate reader (Multiskan SkyHigh, Thermo Scientific, USA) at a wavelength of 517 nm. Vitamin E (VE, 3.125–100 µg/mL) was utilized as a positive control. Scavenging activity was calculated via the following formula:
The absorbance of the sample with DPPH is represented as At, Ab represents the absorbance of the sample without DPPH, and A0 represents the absorbance of DPPH without any sample.

Using the method described by Sornsenee [25], the scavenging activity of the sample against the ABTS radical cation (ABTS⁺) was determined. Briefly, ABTS+ was produced by combining 7 mM ABTS (Macklin, Shanghai, China) and 2.45 mM K2S2O8 (Macklin, Shanghai, China) in a 1:1 (v/v) ratio. The ABTS+ mixture was maintained in darkness at room temperature for 12 h. The freshly prepared ABTS⁺ solution was diluted to achieve an absorbance of 0.70 ± 0.02 at 734 nm in a microplate reader. In a 96-well plate, 40 µL of the sample, with a concentration range of 1–10 mg/mL, was combined with 160 µL of ABTS⁺ solution. After a 6-minute incubation, the absorbance was measured at 734 nm. Vitamin C (VC, 1.5625–50 µg/mL) was utilized as a positive control. The ABTS+ radical scavenging activity was calculated as follows:
where A1 is the absorbance of the sample mixed with the ABTS+ solution and A0 is the absorbance of the deionized water mixed with the ABTS+ solution.

The ferric reducing antioxidant power (FRAP) of the samples was assessed via the methodology established by Yang [26]. The working FRAP solution was prepared by mixing TPTZ (10 mmol/L, Shanghai Yuanye Bio-Technology Co., Ltd., Shanghai, China), ferric trichloride (FeCl3, 20 mmol/L, Macklin Shanghai, China), and sodium acetate buffer (pH = 3.6, 300 mmol/L, NaAc, Macklin Shanghai, China) at a 1:1:10 (v/v) ratio. The reaction was initiated by adding 80 µL of sample (10–60 mg/mL) to 120 µL of FRAP solution. The mixture was incubated for 30 min at 37 °C in the dark. After incubation, the absorbance of the mixture was measured at 593 nm in a microplate reader. Water solutions of FeSO4•7H2O (1–10 mmol/L, Macklin, Shanghai, China) were used to calibrate the instrument, and the results are expressed as the FRAP value (mM Fe2+). VC (6.25–200 µg/mL) was utilized as positive control. The antioxidant capacity was positively correlated with the FRAP value.

sec.title: Assessment of antioxidant activity via a ROS assay
sec.p: ROS levels were quantified using 2’, 7’-dichlorodihydrofluorescein diacetate (DCFH-DA) fluorescent probe according to the methodology established by Borja-Martínez [27]. HaCaT cells were seeded at 3 × 105 cells/well in 12-well plates and incubated overnight. Four distinct groups were established for the purposes of this study: a normal group, a model group, and two sample groups (unfermented and fermented A. cochinchinensis). In both the normal and model groups, 1 mL of serum-free DMEM was added after removal of the medium. The sample groups received 1 mL of serum-free DMEM containing test samples. After a 24 h incubation period, the medium was removed, and a layer of PBS was added to fully cover the cells. The cells, in addition to those in the normal group, were then exposed to UVB. After exposure, fresh DMEM was added to replace the PBS, and the cells were incubated for 8 h. After the medium was removed, the cells were incubated with the fluorescence probe DCFH-DA for 30 min in the dark at 37 °C, followed by two washes with PBS. The cells were examined using an inverted fluorescence microscope, and the mean fluorescence intensity was quantified.

sec.title: Determination of intracellular antioxidant enzymes and extracellular matrix factors
sec.p: HaCaT cells were inoculated into 12-well plates at a density of 2 × 10⁵ cells per well, utilizing 1 mL of DMEM supplemented with 10% foetal bovine serum and penicillin‒streptomycin. The cell treatment protocol was the same as that described above. The culture supernatants and cell lysis supernatants were collected for tests. The concentrations of human matrix metalloproteinase 1 (MMP-1), Procollagen I N-terminal peptide-1 (PINP-1) and haem oxygenase-1 (HO-1) were measured via enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) kits purchased from JianglaiBio (Shanghai, China) following the manufacturer’s instructions. Superoxide dismutase (SOD) and catalase (CAT) assay kits (Nanjing Jiancheng Bioengineering Institute, Nanjing, China) were used to determine the contents of SOD and CAT in the HaCaT cells after treatment according to the protocols outlined by the manufacturer.

sec.title: qPCR
sec.p: HaCaT cells were plated at a density of 3.5 × 10⁵ cells per well in 6-well plates and incubated for 24 h. The cell treatment protocol was the same as that described previously. The RNA was extracted from HaCaT cells via the RNAprep Pure Cell/Bacteria Kit (TIANGEN, Beijing, China) following the provided guidelines. The synthesis of cDNA was completed via the Revert Aid First Strand cDNA Synthesis Kit (Thermo Scientific, MA, USA). qPCR amplification was performed via TB Green Premix (Takara, Beijing, China) and qPCR (CFX connect, Bio-Rad, CA, USA). The specific sequences of the primers utilized in this research are presented in Table 2. Gene expression levels were assessed via the 2−ΔΔCt method. GAPDH was used as an internal control [28], with three replicate wells established for each sample.

sec.title: Metabolite extraction
sec.p: One hundred microlitres of the sample after dissolution was introduced into 400 µL of anhydrous methanol within a 2 mL Eppendorf tube and thoroughly mixed by means of shaking. The samples were then placed in a -20 °C freezer for 30 min, during which time precipitation of the proteins occurred. The samples were centrifuged, and the supernatant was transferred to another Eppendorf tube. After lyophilization, the supernatant was redissolved by adding 100 µL of 50% methanol solution to the tube. Finally, the samples were centrifuged again and transferred to the injection bottle for ultrahigh-performance liquid chromatography-high-resolution mass spectrometry (UPLC-HRMS). A total of 10–20 µL of extract from each sample was mixed to prepare qualified consultant (QC) samples for UPLC-HRMS.

sec.title: Instrument parameters
sec.p: Reversed-phase chromatographic separation was conventionally executed with an ACQUITY UPLC HSS T3 column, characterized by dimensions of 100 mm × 2.1 mm and a pore diameter of 1.8 μm (Waters, UK). Column temperature: 40 °C; flow rate: 0.35 mL/min. Mobile phase: Eluent A: 5 mmol/L ammonium acetate + 5 mmol/L acetic acid + 1 L water; Eluent B: acetonitrile. The gradient elution conditions were as follows: 0–1 min, 1% Eluent B; 1–9.5 min, 1–99% Eluent B; 9.5–11.5 min, 99% Eluent B; 11.5–12.0 min, 99–1% Eluent B; and 12–15 min, 1% Eluent B.

The metabolites that were eluted from the column were identified via a high-resolution tandem mass spectrometer, the Triple TOF-6600 (SCIEX, Framingham, MA, USA). The mass spectrometer was operated with the following parameters in positive or negative polarity mode: shear gas flow rate: 60 PSI, aux gas flow rate: 60 psi, capillary temperature: 500 °C. Using the information-dependent acquisition (IDA) method, mass spectrometry data were obtained. The time-of-flight (TOF) mass range extended from 60 to 1200 Da, with a scan duration of 0.15 s. The top 12 signal ions with signal accumulation intensities exceeding 100 from the primary map were subsequently selected for secondary fragmentation scanning. Dynamic exclusion was set for 4 s. QC samples were scanned at intervals of 10 samples during the acquisition. The discrepancy in quality between QCs was employed to address the issue of systematic errors in batch experiments.

sec.title: Data processing
sec.p: The raw data files from UPLC-HRMS were transformed into mzXML format and subsequently analysed via XCMS, CAMERA, and the metaX toolbox, all of which were executed within the R programming environment [29]. By integrating the mass‒charge ratio (m/z) data with the retention time (RT), each ion was found. Metabolites were identified and classified via the online resources provided by the KEGG and HMDB databases. To identify and assess any potential batch effects within the pre-processed dataset, a principal component analysis (PCA) was conducted. A robust LOESS signal correction was applied to the QC data in relation to the order of injection, with the intention of reducing the impact of potential signal intensity drift over time. Furthermore, all the QC samples were utilized to compute the relative standard deviations (RSD) for the metabolic features. Features with RSD values exceeding 30% were omitted from subsequent analysis. To evaluate the differences in metabolite concentrations between the two phenotypes, the primary statistical method employed was Student’s t test. To accommodate the multiplicity of statistical tests performed, the p value was modified through the application of the Benjamini‒Hochberg adjustment (false discovery rate; FDR). Within the metaX framework, supervised partial least squares discriminant analysis (PLS-DA) was utilized to effectively differentiate variables among distinct groups. A variable importance in projection (VIP) value was computed, with a VIP threshold of 1.0 established to identify the most significant variables.

sec.title: Measurement of amino acid content
sec.p: All samples were hydrolysed with 6 M hydrochloric acid at 110 °C for 22 h. After cooling, the hydrolysate was quantitatively transferred to a 25 mL volumetric flask. The hydrolysis tube was rinsed repeatedly with deionized water, and the combined rinses were used to bring the solution to volume. The resulting solution was then filtered. A 1 mL aliquot of the filtrate was dried under vacuum in a desiccator at 45 ± 5 °C. The residue was reconstituted in 1 mL of deionized water and dried again. This residue was dried to completeness. The dried material was dissolved in 1 mL of 0.02 mol/L hydrochloric acid solution, passed through a 0.22 μm aqueous phase microporous membrane filter, and prepared for subsequent injection. The amino acid content in the processed sample was determined using a Sykam S433D fully automatic amino acid analyzer.

Chromatographic Conditions: Separation was performed on a sulfonated cation-exchange resin column (4.6 mm × 60 mm, 3 μm particle size). The mobile phase flow rate was 0.4 mL/min, and the derivatization reagent flow rate was 0.35 mL/min. The separation column temperature was maintained at 57 °C, while the reaction column temperature was set at 135 °C. The injection volume was 20 µL. Detection wavelengths were set at 440 nm for proline and 570 nm for all other amino acids. Quantification was based on peak areas, and the concentrations of individual amino acids were determined using the external standard method.

sec.title: Measurement of sarsasapogenin content
sec.p: According to Tang’s method [30], an LC-20AD high-performance liquid chromatography instrument (Shimadzu, Japan) was employed to quantitatively analyse the sarsasapogenin components in the extracts of A.cochinchinensis before and after fermentation. Approximately 0.15 g of the freeze-dried powder of the A. cochinchinensis extract and the TD103 fermentation product were accurately weighed and placed in conical flasks. Then, 10 mL of ethanol was added, and ultrasonic treatment (250 W, 40 kHz) was conducted for 20 min. Subsequently, the solutions were filtered through a microporous membrane (0.45 μm), and the filtrates were used as the test solutions. The standard substance sarsasapogenin solution was prepared with concentrations ranging from 0.0125 mg/mL to 0.8 mg/mL. Chromatographic conditions were as follows: The chromatographic column was a Waters Sun Fire C18 (250 mm × 4.6 mm, 5 μm). The mobile phase consisted of methanol-water (90:10), with a flow rate of 1.0 mL/min. The column temperature was maintained at 30 °C, the drift tube temperature of the evaporative light scattering detector was set at 45 °C, nitrogen was used as the nebulizing gas with a pressure of 486 kPa. The injection volumes were 5 µL and 15 µL for the reference substance solutions and 10 µL for the test solution. Quantification was conducted using the external standard two-point method. Regression analysis was performed by plotting the natural logarithm of the reference substance solution concentration (X) against the natural logarithm of the peak area (Y). The resulting regression equation was y = 0.8818x-3.0001, with a coefficient of determination (R²) of 0.9948. Based on this, the content of sarsasapogenin in the samples was determined.

sec.title: Antifungal susceptibility testing
sec.p: The antifungal susceptibilities of Fluconazole, Itraconazole, Ketoconazole, Terbinafine, and Amphotericin B against the TD103 strain were determined by the microbroth dilution method in CLSI’s M38-A2 [31]. The experiment was conducted in a 96-well plate. Specifically, 100 µL of RPMI − 1640 medium was added to the wells in columns 3–11, and 200 µL of the drug dilution solution was added to column 2. Subsequently, 100 µL of the solution from column 2 was pipetted into column 3, thoroughly mixed, and then 100 µL was successively transferred to columns 4–11, with 100 µL discarded from column 11. Next, 100 µL of the fungal suspension (0.5 × 104-5 × 104 CFU/mL) was added to columns 1–11 (where column 1 served as the growth control and column 12, containing 100 µL of RPMI-1640, served as the blank control). Each drug was replicated in triplicate. Following 48-hour incubation at 35 °C, the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) was determined microscopically.

sec.title: Fungal toxin detection
sec.p: TD103 fungal spores were inoculated into sabouraud liquid medium and incubated at 28 °C for 7 days. Subsequently, the fermentation broth was collected for mycotoxin determination. In accordance with the instructions from manufacturer, aflatoxin B1, ochratoxin A, and deoxynivalenol detection test strips (Finde (Beijing) Environmental Technology Co., Ltd.) were employed to assay the fermentation broth of strain TD103.

sec.title: Irritation tests
sec.p: secH: average bleeding time of the membrane.
secL: average time of vascular melting in the membrane.
secC: average time of coagulation in the membrane.
The classification of the level of ocular irritation induced by the substance under examination was founded on the IS values presented in Table 3.

caption.p: Evaluation results of stimulus scoring method

sec.p: A sample was considered non-irritating if the concentration was less than 20% [34].

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: The experiments were conducted in triplicate, and the results are presented as the mean ± standard deviation. The significance of multiple means was determined via analysis of variance. A statistically significant difference was assessed at a threshold of p < 0.05. All analyses were conducted with the aid of SPSS version 24.0. for Windows (SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL, USA).

sec.title: Screening of endophytic fungal fermentation products with photoprotective effects
sec.p: A total of 5 endophytic fungi were isolated from A. cochinchinensis. Among the five prepared fermentation products, the TD103 fermentation product demonstrated strongest cell-protective activity. After treatment with the TD103 fermentation product, the viability of UVB-damaged cells was maintained at 98.63 ± 1.22% (Fig. 1A). Therefore, in the subsequent study, we selected the fermentation product of TD103 as the research focus to investigate the enhancing effect of endophytic fungal fermentation on the photoprotective properties of A. cochinchinensis.

caption.p: Screening of endophytic fungal fermentation products (A) Screening of fermented A. cochinchinensis exhibiting photo-protective properties (ns p > 0.05, * p < 0.05, ** p < 0.01, *** p < 0.001 compared with the normal group). (B) Protection of UVB-damaged skin cells by unfermented control and TD103-fermented A. cochinchinensis (ns p > 0.05, * p < 0.05, ** p < 0.01, *** p < 0.001, **** p < 0.0001 compared with the model and unfermented control groups, ## p < 0.01, ### p < 0.001, #### p < 0.0001 compared with the normal group). Each value is expressed as mean ± SD (n = 3)

sec.p: To determine the potential protective effects of fermented A. cochinchinensis by TD103 on UVB-irradiated HaCaT cells, additional experiments were performed. As shown in Fig. 1B, cell viability was markedly greater in the sample groups than in the model group (p < 0.001). The uninoculated control demonstrated protective effects on HaCaT cells at concentrations of 0.2, 0.4 and 0.6 mg/mL. Compared with the uninoculated control, fermented A. cochinchinensis by TD103 at all the tested concentrations resulted in greater viability. Considering the viability and status of the cells, a moderate concentration (0.6 mg/mL) was selected for subsequent experiments.

Subsequently, morphological and molecular biological identification of TD103 was conducted. The fungal isolate TD103 displayed characteristics of white mycelium and brown spores (Fig. 2A). After staining with lactic acid phenol cotton blue (Fig. 2B), the sporophore of TD103 displayed an enlarged acrosome at the upper end, which was characterized by the production of a distinctive bottle-like peduncle. This structure expanded in a radial manner, bearing conidia in bunches at its tip. These morphological characteristics were consistent with those of Aspergillus sp. The ITS rDNA sequence of TD103 (GenBank accession number: OR905556) shared 99.81% similarity with the Aspergillus aculeatus isolate SQZ17 (Accession No: ON209520.1). Strain TD103 was found to well cluster with seven Aspergillus taxa in the analysis of the ITS1-5.8 S-ITS2 region (Fig. 3). Within this clade, the strain TD103 and A. aculeatus isolate SQZ17 (ON209520.1) formed a subclade with a strong bootstrap support of 100%. Therefore, the strain TD103 was identified as A. aculeatus.

caption.p: The colony (A) and spores (B) morphology of endophytic fungus TD103

Phylogenetic tree based on the ITSrDNA gene sequence of endophytic fungus TD103. Diaporthe discoidispora isolate NKDL-2(MN816409.1) was used as the out-group. Numbers at the branch points are the bootstrap values based on 1,000 resampling. The scale bar represents 0.02 nucleotide changes per position. GenBank accession numbers were shown in parentheses

sec.title: Effect of endophytic fungal fermentation on antioxidant activity in vitro
sec.p: The capacity of both unfermented and fermented A. cochinchinensis to scavenge radicals was investigated. The samples were evaluated at various concentrations (1–10 mg/mL) to determine their scavenging ability. Figure 4A showed the percentages of DPPH scavenging by the unfermented A. cochinchinensis, which ranged from 23.95 ± 0.57% to 63.12 ± 0.60%. However, fermented A. cochinchinensis exhibited greater scavenging activity against DPPH free radicals (p < 0.05). The DPPH scavenging percentages exhibited by fermented A. cochinchinensis varied between 28.69 ± 0.92% and 78.85 ± 0.58%, although this activity was much lower than VE. The IC50 values of unfermented and fermented A. cochinchinensis for the DPPH radical scavenging activities were 6.14 mg/mL and 3.58 mg/mL, respectively. The IC50 values of VE was 49.34 µg/mL.

caption.p: Antioxidant activities of the unfermented and fermented A. cochinchinensis (A) DPPH scavenging activity (B) ABTS scavenging activity (C) FRAP values. Each value is expressed as mean ± SD (n = 3)

sec.p: Furthermore, the ABTS+ scavenging activity observed in the unfermented A. cochinchinensis ranged from 2.08 ± 1.28% to 79.87 ± 0.30% (Fig. 4B). Fermentation of A. cochinchinensis significantly increased ABTS+ scavenging activity as well. The percentages of ABTS+ scavenged by fermented A. cochinchinensis ranged from 8.63 ± 0.44% to 87.14 ± 0.48%. Similarly, the clearance rate of both was much lower than that of VC. The IC50 values of unfermented and fermented A. cochinchinensis for the ABTS+ scavenging activities were 5.51 mg/mL and 4.63 mg/mL, respectively. The IC50 values of VC was 15.81 µg/mL.

Ferric reducing antioxidant power (FRAP) serves as a metric for evaluating the reducing capabilities of antioxidants by examining their ability to convert Fe(III)-TPTZ to Fe(II)-TPTZ [35]. The samples were assessed at various concentrations ranging from 10 to 60 mg/mL. The FRAP value of unfermented and fermented A. cochinchinensis was expressed as mmol of ferrous sulphate (FS) per litre and is shown in Fig. 4C. The FRAP value of the unfermented control ranged from 1.23 ± 0.02mM to 2.19 ± 0.01 mM. The FRAP value of fermented A. cochinchinensis ranged from 1.71 ± 0.02mM to 2.70 ± 0.02 mM. The FRAP value of VC ranged from 0.36 ± 0.00 mM to 0.95 ± 0.00 mM. Compared with the unfermented control, fermented A. cochinchinensis presented greater ferric reducing antioxidant power, supporting the findings from the radical scavenging tests (p < 0.05).

sec.title: Effects of fermented A. cochinchinensis on ROS Inhibition
sec.p: Figure 5 delineated the effects of UVB radiation-induced cellular damage and elucidates the protective efficacy of the samples in modulating ROS levels in HaCaT cells. The normal group, which had not undergone UVB irradiation, exhibited a markedly reduced level of active oxygen, accompanied by diminished fluorescence and a weaker overall intensity. After exposure, the level of ROS in the model group was elevated by a factor of 3.2 relative to that in the normal group. However, the administration of samples prior to treatment was demonstrated to reverse these effects. Compared with the model group, the unfermented control and fermented A. cochinchinensis groups presented 45.36% and 61.38% lower intracellular ROS levels, respectively. Compared with the unfermented control group, the fermented A. cochinchinensis group presented better scavenging effects (p < 0.001). The experimental data presented here indicate that fermented A. cochinchinensis is demonstrably more effective than the unfermented control in reducing excess ROS in UVB-irradiated HaCaT cells.

caption.p: Effects of fermented A. cochinchinensis on ROS inhibition (A) Inhibitory effects of unfermented and fermented A. cochinchinensis on the generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in UVB-damaged skin cells (B)Mean fluorescence intensity of ROS in each group (ns p > 0.05, * p < 0.05, ** p < 0.01, *** p < 0.001, **** p < 0.0001 compared with the model and unfermented control groups, ## p < 0.01, ### p < 0.001, #### p < 0.0001 compared with the normal group). Each value is expressed as mean ± SD (n = 3)

sec.title: Effects of fermented A. cochinchinensis on antioxidant enzyme activities
sec.p: Both SOD and CAT are capable of effectively scavenging free radicals and play pivotal roles in the body’s defences against UVB-induced oxidative stress. HO-1 is a stress response protein associated with epidermal differentiation. It possesses the ability to counteract ROS and plays a role in protecting cells against oxidative stress [36].

As shown in Fig. 6A, exposure of HaCaT cells to UVB significantly reduced HO-1 enzyme content, while both unfermented and fermented A. cochinchinensis attenuated this reduction. Compared with the model group, the HO-1 enzyme content in the unfermented A. cochinchinensis group and the fermented A. cochinchinensis group increased by 1.23-fold and 1.96-fold, respectively. Obviously, the fermented A. cochinchinensis group exhibited a more pronounced promoting effect on the HO-1 enzyme content (p < 0.0001). Figure 6B showed the effects of unfermented and fermented A. cochinchinensis on the cellular contents of CAT. Compared with the normal group, the UVB-treated group presented significant decreases in the levels of CAT (p < 0.0001). Treatment of fermented A. cochinchinensis increased the CAT level, while it was not affected by treatment with unfermented A. cochinchinensis. Figure 6C depicted the effects of unfermented and fermented A. cochinchinensis on SOD content. After UVB exporsure, the SOD content was reduced to 5.76 ± 0.19U/mg protein. However, in the unfermented and fermented A. cochinchinensis groups, the SOD content increased to 8.16 ± 0.38 U/mgprot and 9.24 ± 0.74 U/mgprot, respectively. These results indicate that fermented A. cochinchinensis may reduce the oxidative stress more effectively caused by UVB radiation by increasing the activity of intrinsic antioxidant enzymes.

caption.p: Effect of unfermented control and fermented A. cochinchinensis on the content of (A) HO-1 enzyme (B) CAT enzyme (C) SOD enzyme in UVB-damaged skin cells (ns p > 0.05, * p < 0.05, ** p < 0.01, *** p < 0.001 compared with the model and unfermented control groups, ## p < 0.01, ### p < 0.001, #### p < 0.0001 compared with the normal group). Each value is expressed as mean ± SD (n = 3)

sec.title: Effects of fermented A. cochinchinensis on the expression of MMP-1 and PINP
sec.p: A comprehensive review of research findings indicates that the substantial production of matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) and subsequent breakdown of collagen triggered by UVB radiation play a primary role in the pathogenesis of cutaneous photodamage, which is clinically defined as skin photoaging [37]. The primary MMP in UV-exposed skin was quantified via the use of collagen-degrading MMP-1 as a marker. The concentrations of amino terminal procollagen propeptides of type I (PINP) were evaluated to determine the rate of collagen synthesis in the skin in vivo. The results revealed that fermented A. cochinchinensis treatment downregulated the UVB-induced overexpression of MMP-1 (p < 0.05), whereas unfermented control treatment even upregulated MMP expression (Fig. 7A). In addition, UVB alone markedly reduced PINP in HaCaT cells, whereas both the unfermented control and fermented A. cochinchinensis groups presented markedly elevated PINP levels in UVB-stimulated cells (p < 0.0001) (Fig. 7B). Compared with the unfermented treatment, the fermented A. cochinchinensis treatment resulted in greater improvement (p < 0.05). These findings suggested that fermented A. cochinchinensis could serve as a preventative measure for UVB-induced photoaging by downregulation of MMP-1 and the upregulation of PINP in HaCaT cells.

caption.p: Effect of unfermented control and fermented A. cochinchinensis on (A) MMP-1 (B) PINP protein content in UVB-damaged HaCaT cells (ns p > 0.05, * p < 0.05, ** p < 0.01, *** p < 0.001, **** p < 0.0001 compared with the model and unfermented control groups, ## p < 0.01, ### p < 0.001, #### p < 0.0001 compared with the normal group). Each value is expressed as mean ± SD (n = 3)

sec.title: Effects of fermented A. cochinchinensis on the gene expression of the AP-1 and MMPs
sec.p: The UV-inducible transcription factor AP-1, which comprises the proteins c-Jun and c-Fos, has been shown to significantly influence the transcriptional levels of a number of MMPs by modulating AP-1 transcriptional activity [38]. To assess the changes in the mRNA expression levels of MMP and AP-1 in HaCaT cells that have been exposed to UVB, it is necessary to quantify the effects of the samples under investigation via quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) analysis. Results at the gene level suggest that the activation of AP-1 was successfully inhibited solely by fermented A. cochinchinensis (Fig. 8A, B). Compared with the model group, the levels of c-Jun and c-Fos mRNA expression decreased by 39.73% and 33.41%, respectively. As shown in Fig. 8C, D, UVB exposure resulted in 243.53% and 256.50% increases in MMP-1 and MMP-9 mRNA expression, respectively. In contrast to the unfermented control, fermented A. cochinchinensis exhibited a more potent inhibitory effect on MMP mRNA expression (p < 0.05).

caption.p: Effect of unfermented control and fermented A. cochinchinensis on the gene expression of (A) c-Jun (B) c-Fos (C) MMP1 (D) MMP9 genes in UVB-damaged HaCaT cells (ns p > 0.05, * p < 0.05, ** p < 0.01, *** p < 0.001, **** p < 0.0001 compared with the model and unfermented control groups, ## p < 0.01, ### p < 0.001, #### p < 0.0001 compared with the normal group). Each value is expressed as mean ± SD (n = 3)

sec.title: Untargeted metabolomics analysis
sec.p: The PCA score plot (Fig. 9) demonstrated that the outcomes of the six experimental groups were significantly different between the unfermented control and fermented A. cochinchinensis. A total of 5.52% and 56.29% of the observed variation in the data were accounted for by PC1 and PC2, respectively. The PLSDA score map clearly shows separation, indicating significant differences in metabolite accumulation between the two samples (Fig. 10A). Additionally, the results from the validation of the rankings suggest that there were no indications of overfitting in the PLSDA model. (Fig. 10B). The criterion can be stated as follows: the value of R2 is greater than that of Q2. Furthermore, the value of Q2 is less than zero, as is the case with the Y-axis. It is justifiable to assert that the model developed in this research is both precise and statistically robust, rendering it appropriate for application in future data analyses.

caption.p: PCA score plots of (1) unfermented A. cochinchinensis and (2) fermented A. cochinchinensis metabolite peaks
(A) PLSDA model score (B) Permutation test diagram

sec.p: Furthermore, VIP values can be employed to identify the metabolites that exhibit differential expression in OPLS-DA. The metabolites with VIP values of ≥ 1 was significantly different, with changes in differentially abundant metabolites identified when combined with FC values of ≥ 2 or ≤ 0.5 and p < 0.05.

As illustrated by the volcano map (Fig. S1), the number of increased and decreased metabolites was 125 and 170, respectively, when the fermented A. cochinchinensis was compared with the unfermented control.

In Fig. 11, the major differentially abundant metabolite classes were organic acids and derivatives (96), lipids and lipid-like molecules (67), organic oxygen compounds (35), organ heterocyclic compounds (30), phenylpropanoids and polyketides (25), and benzenoids (24).

caption.p: Statistical plot of the number of differential metabolites

sec.p: A comprehensive analysis of metabolic pathways yielded a total of 85 differential pathways (Fig. S2). According to an enrichment factor > 0.15, the top 8 metabolic pathways were as follows: (1) Glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)-anchor biosynthesis, phosphatidylethanolamine and 1-phosphatidyl-D-myo-inositol were identified in this pathway. (2) In the aminoacyl-tRNA biosynthesis pathway, fourteen metabolites, including L-glutamate, L-tyrosine, and L-phenylalanine, were identified. (3) Alanine, aspartate, and glutamate metabolism involves five metabolites, namely, succinate, L-aspartate, and citrate. (4) Arginine biosynthesis involved metabolites such as L-glutamate-aspartate-arginine and L-citrulline. (5) In terms of phenylalanine metabolism, a total of twelve metabolites were identified, including N-acetyl-L-phenylalanine, phenyl lactate, and 2-hydroxyphenylacetate. (6) In the biosynthesis of plant hormones, eleven metabolites, including trans-cinamate, indole-3-acetate and gibberellin A12 aldehyde, were identified. (7) ABC transporters involved twenty metabolites, such as sucrose, nitrate, D-sorbitol, and trehalose. (8) Regarding glycerophospholipid metabolism, eight metabolites, including choline and cardiolipin, were identified.

sec.title: Changes in amino acid content of A. cochinchinensis fermented with TD103
sec.p: Analysis of 18 amino acids in A. cochinchinensis extract before and after fermentation revealed significant decreases in the content of aspartic acid, serine, histidine, and arginine. No significant changes were observed in the levels of the other amino acids analysed. Among these, histidine exhibited the most pronounced reduction, decreasing by 62.19% (Table 4).

caption.p: Amino acid contents in A. cochinchinensis before and after fermentation(n = 3)

table-wrap-foot.p: Note: Different superscript letters denote statistically significant differences (p < 0.05)

sec.title: Changes in sarsasapogenin content of A. cochinchinensis fermented with TD103
sec.p: To assess the alterations in sarsasapogenin contents throughout the fermentation process, an HPLC system integrated with a charged aerosol detector was employed. As depicted in Fig. 12, upon analysing the A. cochinchinensis extracts before and after fermentation, a notable increase in peak height was observed at a retention time of 16.14 min. Through the comparison of an external standard, this peak was conclusively identified as sarsasapogenin. Quantitatively, a remarkable transformation occurred in the content of sarsasapogenin within the A. cochinchinensis extract. Specifically, it increased from 26.25 µg/mg to 75 µg/mg after fermentation.

caption.p: HPLC chromatography of sarsasapogenin (A) before fermentation (B) after fermentation

sec.title: Safety determination
sec.p: The results of the microdilution method for antifungal susceptibility testing indicated that strain TD103 was sensitive to Fluconazole (MIC: 1 µg/mL), Itraconazole (MIC: 0.0625 µg/mL), Ketoconazole (MIC: 0.5 µg/mL), Terbinafine (MIC: 0.0625 µg/mL), and Amphotericin B (MIC: 0.125 µg/mL) (Table 5). No aflatoxin B1, ochratoxin, or deoxynivalenol was detected in the TD103 fungal fermentation broth, suggesting its good safety (Fig. S3).

caption.p: MICs of five antifungal drugs against TD103 (n = 3)

sec.p: Figure S4 depicted the impact of the stimulation on the blood vessels, both in its absence and after the introduction of the samples. The negative and positive controls were treated with 0.9% NaCl and 0.1 mol/L NaOH, respectively. The positive control had a stimulation score of 17.96 points, indicating considerable vascular haemolysis and marked irritation. Conversely, the negative control had a score of 0.01 points, indicating the absence of vascular haemolysis. The unfermented control group presented a stimulation score of 0.03, whereas the fermented A. cochinchinensis group presented a score of 0.02. Neither group exhibited haemolysis or stimulation, and the findings demonstrate outstanding safety.

Figure 13 showed the histogram of haemolysis rates for unfermented and fermented A. cochinchinensis at various concentrations. The arrangement of the columns, extending from left to right, is as follows: haemolysis control (0.4% SDS), negative control (PBS), sample solution (unfermented control and TD103 fermented A. cochinchinensis, 0.2–1 mg/mL). The erythrocyte haemolysis test results prove that both the unfermented control and fermented A. cochinchinensis had extremely low red blood cell haemolysis rates (below 3%) and no stimulating effects.

caption.p: Erythrocyte hemolysis rates of samples at different concentrations. Each value is expressed as mean ± SD (n = 3)

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Excessive ROS generation induced by UVB radiation can lead to skin damage. These ROS can subsequently result in damage to DNA, lipid peroxidation, protein modification and subsequent degradation. Signalling pathways associated with cellular survival, the ageing process, and the inflammatory response are subsequently activated by compromised molecules [39]. To prevent the occurrence of skin disorders, it is vital to either avoid excessive exposure to ultraviolet radiation or use products that are designed to offer UVB protection.

Research has demonstrated that A. cochinchinensis is rich in bioactive compounds, including saponins, essential amino acids, polysaccharides, and various other substances that exhibit significant antioxidant and anti-inflammatory activities. Microbial fermentation technology permits an augmented release of the plant’s active ingredients, with an emphasis on the exploitation of endophytic fungi with a heightened affinity for substrates. To date, the potential of fermented A. cochinchinensis to resist photodamage to the skin has not been investigated.

The current study utilized microbial fermentation techniques to assess the effects of endophytic Aspergillus on A. cochinchinensis, with a focus on the protective capacity of unfermented versus fermented A. cochinchinensis samples.

Keratinocytes are considered an exemplary cellular model for examining cutaneous barrier dysfunction and are commonly used to elucidate the underlying mechanisms of UVB radiation-induced inflammatory responses [40]. Accordingly, this study constructed an in vitro model of UVB-induced damage to HaCaT cells with the objective of investigating the cytoprotective role and underlying mechanism of action of fermented A. cochinchinensis in preventing oxidative damage and skin ageing resulting from UVB irradiation. The results demonstrated that TD103-fermented A. cochinchinensis exhibited a more significant effect on cell protection compared to the unfermented counterpart.

The endophytic fungus TD103 identified in this study as Aspergillus aculeatus possesses a diverse enzyme system, capable of secreting enzymes such as amylase, acid protease, cellulase, and glucose oxidase [41]. This microorganism is an important fermentation agent, widely utilized in the production of food industrial enzyme preparations and processes good safety [42, 43]. However, given its fermentation-enhancing ability and the low irritation of its fermentation products, we propose that A. aculeatus holds potential for practical applications.

The antioxidant properties of the samples were extensively investigated via free radical scavenging and FRAP assays. DPPH is recognized as a stable free radical donor and has been extensively utilized in research examining the free radical scavenging properties of natural antioxidants [44]. ABTS+, with an amphiphilic structure, is eliminated in a process whereby the transferred electron simultaneously transfers hydrogen. Consequently, it is also commonly employed for the evaluation of antioxidant properties [45]. The FRAP method is a straightforward, user-friendly, reproducible, and readily standardizable approach that effectively quantifies total antioxidant activity. In this study, compared with unfermented A. cochinchinensis, fermented A. cochinchinensis had a greater ability to scavenge free radicals and reduce iron in vitro. Therefore, fermentation of A. cochinchinensis by the endophytic fungus TD103 enhances the in vitro antioxidant capacity of A. cochinchinensis.

UVB radiation has been reported to induce oxidative stress by increasing the production of ROS such as superoxide radicals, hydroxyl radicals and hydrogen peroxide, and conversely, to suppress the activity of endogenous antioxidants, such as catalase, SOD, and HO-1 [46]. This could result in oxidative damage to the skin. The results of the DCFH-DA assays indicated that both unfermented and fermented A. cochinchinensis were capable of effectively mitigating the intracellular ROS induced by UVB irradiation. However, fermented A. cochinchinensis presented increased efficacy. A similar trend was observed in the antioxidant enzyme system. The findings indicated that treatment using fermented A. cochinchinensis notably increased the expression levels of antioxidant enzymes, which in turn improved the redox balance in cells subjected to UVB irradiation.

The key drivers of skin ageing, including the formation of wrinkles, a loss of elasticity and a general loosening of the skin, are alterations in the collagen and elastin fibres found within the extracellular matrix (ECM). These changes are attributed to the elevated expression of enzymes that degrade collagen and elastin fibres. In particular, MMP-1 is upregulated and plays a crucial role in the degradation of ECM components in UV-exposed skin [47]. The propeptide of type I collagen, PINP, in HaCaT cells functions as a sensitive biomarker for the synthesis of type I collagen, the predominant collagen type found in the skin [48]. The results unequivocally indicate that fermented A. cochinchinensis treatment markedly reduces the protein level of MMP-1. Moreover, the administration of fermented A. cochinchinensis resulted in a notable increase in PINP levels. These observations indicate that the administration of fermented A. cochinchinensis can mitigate the deterioration of the extracellular matrix in UVB-damaged keratinocytes. The MMP-1 concentration in the uninoculated control group was higher than in the UVB-treated groups. However, the relative level of MMP-1 mRNA in the uninoculated control group was lower than that in the UVB-treated groups, which is not consistent with the protein level. This phenomenon might be attributable to the inhibitory effects of unfermented A. cochinchinensis extract on translational regulation, potentially leading to discordance between mRNA expression profiles and corresponding protein abundance within treatment groups.

Empirical studies have demonstrated that UVB irradiation stimulates the generation of ROS, which in turn activate MMPs. This activation results in the degradation of collagen and other extracellular matrix proteins, a process mediated by AP-1. AP-1 functions as a dimer, and its assembly is facilitated by the phosphorylation of ERK, p38, JNK, and MAPK [49]. To initially explore the mechanisms through which unfermented and fermented A. cochinchinensis confer a protective effect on the skin, the expression of key genes within the AP-1 pathway was examined. Interestingly, the treatment of HaCaT cells with fermented A. cochinchinensis attenuated UVB-induced AP-1 activation and suppressed the levels of MMP mRNA. We will verify this mechanism by investigating this at other levels in future experiments.

Metabolomics has been extensively used as an analytical tool for qualitative and quantitative evaluations of metabolites, enhancing the comprehension of their interrelationships during fermentation [50]. In this study, the species of differentially abundant metabolites and their relative contents were analysed for the first time in unfermented A. cochinchinensis and that fermented by endophytic fungi via UPLC-HRMS. In total, 295 differentially abundant metabolites were identified. Metabolites associated with photoprotective activity predominantly accumulate within the synthesis pathways of steroids, terpenoids, amino acids, and alkaloids. The identified metabolites were L-tyrosine, L-phenylalanine, trehalose, and sarsasapogenin. Tyrosine (L-tyrosine, Tyr) is a nutritionally essential amino acid that plays a pivotal role in the metabolism, growth and development of humans and animals. The compound was shown to possess antioxidant properties, including anti-lipid peroxidation, reducing ability and free radical scavenging activities, in a series of in vitro tests [51]. Several researchers have reported that L-phenylalanine has a positive effect on physical function. For example, L-phenylalanine plays a role in regulating blood pressure (BP), with phenylalanine preventing increases in BP that can occur with increasing age and heart weight (heart/body weight index) [52]. Trehalose is a nonreducing disaccharide composed of two D-glucose molecules connected by α-1,1 glycosidic bonds. It is found in a wide range of nonmammalian organisms, such as bacteria, fungi, plants, and invertebrates. Research indicates that trehalose possesses cytoprotective properties under various conditions of cellular stress, including oxidative damage, dehydration, and temperature variations [53]. Sarsasapogenin is a well-known biologically active compound in A. cochinchinensis that has antioxidant and anti-inflammatory activity, which was recently reported [54]. Via HPLC quantitative analysis, it was discovered that the content of sarsasapogenin in A cochinchinensis increased remarkably following fermentation by the endophytic fungus TD103. This, in turn, enhanced the photoprotective activity of A. cochinchinensis. Furthermore, quantitative analysis of amino acid content revealed significant reductions in four amino acids, likely due to direct consumption by fungi—a finding consistent with previous reports by Mi et al. [55]. Additionally, although non-targeted metabolomics suggested increased levels of L-tyrosine and phenylalanine post-fermentation, no such changes were observed in our targeted measurements. This discrepancy may arise from differences in sample handling protocols between the two analytical approaches, potentially altering amino acid concentrations prior to detection. Consequently, our data revealed no association between amino acid levels and increased functional activity in A. cochinchinensis.

Currently, there are no established safety standards for the utilization of fungi in cosmetics. As a result, we referred to several relevant literature sources to evaluate the safety of fungal strains [56]. The antifungal susceptibility test shows that strain TD103 is sensitive to common antifungal drugs and is a non-resistant strain. Moreover, considering that filamentous fungi might generate certain secondary metabolites that are detrimental to humans during the fermentation process, we conducted tests on several common harmful mycotoxins to assess the toxin-producing characteristics of the strains.

Aflatoxins are a group of carcinogenic mycotoxins produced by Aspergillus fungi. Among these, Aflatoxin B1 (AFB1) is the most toxic one. The metabolites of AFB1 show various pathogenic effects, including acute toxicity, teratogenicity, mutagenicity, and carcinogenicity [57]. Ochratoxins are metabolites produced by Aspergillus and Penicillium fungi. Among them, Ochratoxin A (OTA) is recognized as the most toxic one and exhibits embryotoxic, teratogenic, genotoxic, neurotoxic, and immunosuppressive properties [58]. Deoxynivalenol (DON), a mycotoxin usually causes diarrhea, vomiting, and gastrointestinal inflammation in both humans and animals [59]. In this study, none of the mycotoxins mentioned above were detected. Thus, strain TD103 exhibits great safety of application.

The present study aimed to assess the potential for eye irritation linked to both unfermented and fermented A. cochinchinensis, employing erythrocyte haemolysis and CAM assays as the methodological frameworks. The findings demonstrate that fermented A. cochinchinensis by TD103 is safe and suitable for utilization in the development and advancement of skin care-related products.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this study, endophytic fungal fermentation of A. cochinchinensis was demonstrated to result in enhanced antioxidant and cytoprotective effects against UVB-induced damage. Investigations conducted at the biochemical and cellular levels demonstrated that fermented A. cochinchinensis by endophytic A. aculeatus TD103 provides robust protection for the skin by increasing the levels of antioxidant enzymes, inhibiting collagen degradation in HaCaT cells. Considering its efficacy and safety, fermented A. cochinchinensis may serve as a valuable cosmetic product. Finally, note that the study’s findings are based on in vitro cellular model experiments. In vivo animal models will be necessary to clarify how fermented A. cochinchinensis protects cells from UVB-induced damage and exhibits protective properties.
